pyfoma package

Submodules

pyfoma.algorithms module

Defines common algorithms over FSTs

pyfoma.algorithms.added_weight(fst: FST, weight) → FST[source]

Returns a modified FST, adding weight to the set of final states in the FST.

pyfoma.algorithms.complement(fst: FST) → FST[source]

Returns the complement of an FST.

pyfoma.algorithms.compose(fst1: FST, fst2: FST) → FST[source]

Composition of A,B; will expand an acceptor into 2-tape FST on-the-fly.

pyfoma.algorithms.concatenate(fst1: FST, fst2: FST) → FST[source]

Concatenation of T1T2. No epsilons. May produce non-accessible states.

pyfoma.algorithms.context_restricted(fst: FST, *contexts, rewrite=False) → FST[source]

Returns a modified FST, where self only allowed in the context L1 _ R1, or … , or L_n _ R_n.

pyfoma.algorithms.create_reverse_index(fst: FST) → dict[source]

Returns dictionary of transitions in reverse (indexed by state).

pyfoma.algorithms.cross_product(fst1: FST, fst2: FST, optional: bool = False) → FST[source]

Perform the cross-product of T1, T2 through composition. Keyword arguments: optional – if True, calculates T1:T2 | T1.

pyfoma.algorithms.determinized(fst: ~pyfoma.fst.FST, staterep=<function <lambda>>, oplus=<built-in function min>) → FST[source]

Returns a modified FST, by weighted determinization of FST.

pyfoma.algorithms.determinized_as_dfa(fst: FST) → FST[source]

Returns a modified FST, determinized as a DFA with weight as part of label, then apply unweighted det.

pyfoma.algorithms.determinized_unweighted(fst: FST) → FST[source]

Returns a modified FST, determinized with all zero weights.

pyfoma.algorithms.difference(fst1: FST, fst2: FST) → FST[source]

Returns self-other. Uses the product algorithm.

pyfoma.algorithms.dijkstra(fst: FST, state) → float[source]

The cost of the cheapest path from state to a final state. Go Edsger!

pyfoma.algorithms.eliminate_flags(fst: FST) → FST[source]

Return a modified FST, having equivalent behavior but no flag diacritics.

pyfoma.algorithms.epsilon_closure(fst: FST, state) → dict[source]

Finds, for a state the set of states reachable by epsilon-hopping.

pyfoma.algorithms.epsilon_removed(fst: FST) → FST[source]

Returns a modified FST, creating new epsilon-free FSM equivalent to original.

pyfoma.algorithms.filtered_accessible(fst: FST) → FST[source]

Returns a modified FST, removing states that are not on a path from the initial state.

pyfoma.algorithms.filtered_coaccessible(fst: FST) → FST[source]

Returns a modified FST, removing states and transitions to states that have no path to a final state.

pyfoma.algorithms.find_sourcestates(fst: FST, index, stateset)[source]

Create generator that yields sourcestates for a set of target states. Yields the label, and the set of sourcestates.

pyfoma.algorithms.ignore(fst1: FST, fst2: FST) → FST[source]

A, ignoring intervening instances of B.

pyfoma.algorithms.intersection(fst1: FST, fst2: FST) → FST[source]

Intersection of self and other. Uses the product algorithm.

pyfoma.algorithms.inverted(fst: FST) → FST[source]

Returns a modified FST, calculating the inverse of a transducer, i.e. flips label tuples around.

pyfoma.algorithms.kleene_closure(fst: FST, mode='star') → FST[source]

Returns a modified FST, applying self*. No epsilons here. If mode == ‘plus’, calculate self+.

pyfoma.algorithms.kleene_plus(fst: FST) → FST[source]

Returns a modified FST, applying self+.

pyfoma.algorithms.kleene_star(fst: FST) → FST[source]

Returns a modified FST, applying self*.

pyfoma.algorithms.labelled_states_topology(fst: FST, mode='BFS') → FST[source]

Returns a modified FST, topologically sorting and labelling states with numbers. Keyword arguments: mode – ‘BFS’, i.e. breadth-first search by default. ‘DFS’ is depth-first.

pyfoma.algorithms.mapped_labels(fst: FST, map: dict) → FST[source]

Returns a modified FST, relabeling the transducer with new labels from dictionary mapping.

Example: map_labels(myfst, {'a':'', 'b':'a'})

pyfoma.algorithms.merging_equivalent_states(fst: FST, equivalenceclasses: set) → FST[source]

Merge equivalent states given as a set of sets.

pyfoma.algorithms.minimized(fst: FST) → FST[source]

Returns a modified FST, minimized by constrained reverse subset construction, Hopcroft-ish.

pyfoma.algorithms.minimized_as_dfa(fst: FST) → FST[source]

Returns a modified FST, minimized as a DFA with weight as part of label, then apply unweighted min.

pyfoma.algorithms.minimized_brz(fst: FST) → FST[source]

Returns a modified FST, minimized through Brzozowski’s trick.

pyfoma.algorithms.optional(fst: FST) → FST[source]

Returns a modified FST, calculated as T|’’ .

pyfoma.algorithms.product(fst1: ~pyfoma.fst.FST, fst2: ~pyfoma.fst.FST, finalf=<built-in function any>, oplus=<built-in function min>, pathfollow=<function <lambda>>) → FST[source]

Generates the product FST from fst1, fst2. The helper functions by default produce fst1|fst2.

pyfoma.algorithms.projected(fst: FST, dim=0) → FST[source]

Returns a modified FST, by projecting fst. dim = -1 will get output proj regardless of # of tapes.

pyfoma.algorithms.pushed_weights(fst: FST) → FST[source]

Returns a modified FST, pushing weights toward the initial state. Calls dijkstra and maybe scc.

pyfoma.algorithms.reversed(fst: FST) → FST[source]

Returns a modified FST, reversing the FST, epsilon-free.

pyfoma.algorithms.reversed_e(fst: FST) → FST[source]

Returns a modified FST, reversing the FST, using epsilons.

pyfoma.algorithms.rewritten(fst: FST, *contexts, **flags) → FST[source]

Returns a modified FST, rewriting self in contexts in parallel, controlled by flags.

pyfoma.algorithms.scc(fst: FST) → set[source]

Calculate the strongly connected components of an FST.

This is a basic implementation of Tarjan’s (1972) algorithm. Tarjan, R. E. (1972), “Depth-first search and linear graph algorithms”, SIAM Journal on Computing, 1 (2): 146–160.

Returns a set of frozensets of states, one frozenset for each SCC.

pyfoma.algorithms.trimmed(fst: FST) → FST[source]

Returns a modified FST, removing states that aren’t both accessible and coaccessible.

pyfoma.algorithms.union(fst1: FST, fst2: FST) → FST[source]

Epsilon-free calculation of union of fst1 and fst2.

pyfoma.algorithms.words_cheapest(fst: FST)[source]

A generator to yield all words in order of cost, cheapest first.

pyfoma.algorithms.words_nbest(fst: FST, n) → list[source]

Finds the n cheapest word in an FST, returning a list.

pyfoma.eliminate_flags.eliminate_fst_flags(fst, Xs=None)[source]

Eliminate all flag diacritics from an FST.

Parameters:

  • fst – An FST.

  • Xs – The variables to be eliminated. If None, then all

variables will be eliminated.

Returns:

An FST without flag diacritics with equivalent behavior

to ‘fst’

Return minimal condition for [[$X=={}]] (and [[$X?={}]]) or [[$X!={}]] to fail.

pyfoma.eliminate_flags.equivalent(fst1, fst2)[source]
pyfoma.eliminate_flags.get_value_tests(Xs, ys)[source]

Return a list of tests for [[$X==y]], [[$X?=y]] and [[$X!=y]] flags which valid strings have to pass.

pyfoma.eliminate_flags.set_any(X, ys)[source]

Set variable X to any value in ys.

pyfoma.eliminate_flags.set_neg(X, y, ys)[source]

Set variable X to any value in ys except y.

pyfoma.eliminate_flags.set_pos(X, y)[source]

Set variable X to value y (i.e. [[$X=y]] | [[$X?=y]]).

pyfoma.eliminate_flags.substitute_no_val_flags(fst)[source]

Substitute all flags of form: * [[$VAR]] with [[$VAR!={}]] * [[!$VAR]] with [[$VAR=={}]] * [[$VAR=]] with [[$VAR={}]]

This is done to ensure that all flags have the format VAR_OP_VAL

pyfoma.eliminate_flags.value_restr(X, y, ys, pos)[source]

Return minimal condition for [[$X==y]] (and [[$X?=y]]) or [[$X!=y]] to fail.

class pyfoma.flag.FlagOp(sym: str)[source]

Bases: object

__init__(sym: str)[source]

Creates a Flag diacritic

Parameters:

sym – String representation of flag diacritic

The parameter ‘sym’ should follow the format [[XYZ]], for example “[[$Num=Sg]]”, where:

  1. X is a variable name matching the regex “[$]w+”

2. Y is one of the operators “=” (set value), “==” (check that value equals), “!=” (check that value does not equal) or “$=” (unify to value) 3. Z is a value matching the regex “[$]?w+”. If the value starts with $, then it refers to a variable.

More formally, any flag diacritic needs to match the expression flag.FLAGRE.

check(config: Dict[str, str], val: str) → bool[source]

The operator “==”

static filter_flags(seq: Sequence[str]) → Sequence[str][source]

Filter out flag diacritics from symbol sequence

static is_flag(sym: str) → bool[source]

Check that ‘sym’ matches the format required by FlagOp.__init__

Parameters:

sym – A string

Returns:

True is ‘sym’ is a valid flag diacritic. False,

otherwise.

neg_check(config: Dict[str, str], val: str) → bool[source]

The operator “!=”

setv(config: Dict[str, str], val: str) → bool[source]

The operator “=”

unify(config: Dict[str, str], val: str) → bool[source]

The operator “?=”

pyfoma.fst module

PyFoma Finite-State Tool.

class pyfoma.fst.FST(label: tuple = None, weight=0.0, alphabet={})[source]

Bases: object

__init__(label: tuple = None, weight=0.0, alphabet={})[source]

Creates an FST-structure with a single state.

Parameters:

  • label (tuple) – create a two-state FST that accepts label

  • weight (float) – add a weight to the final state

  • alphabet (set[str]) – declare an alphabet explicitly

If ‘label’ is given, a two-state automaton is created with label as the only transition from the initial state to the final state.

If ‘weight’ is also given, the final state will have that weight. Labels are always tuples internally, so a two-state automaton that only accepts ‘a’ should have label = (‘a’,).

If label is the empty string, i.e. (‘’,), the second state will not be created, but the initial state will be made final with weight ‘weight’.

add_weight(weight) → FST

Mutates the FST, adding weight to the set of final states in the FST.

all_transitions(states)[source]

Enumerate all transitions (state, label, Transition) for an iterable of states.

all_transitions_by_label(states)[source]

Enumerate all transitions by label. Each yield produces a label, and those the target states. ‘states’ is an iterable of source states.

alphabet

The alphabet used by the FST

analyze(word, weights=False, tokenize_outputs=False, obey_flags=True, print_flags=False)[source]

Pass word through FST and return generator that yields all inputs.

apply(word, inverse=False, weights=False, tokenize_outputs=False, obey_flags=True, print_flags=False)[source]

Pass word through FST and return generator that yields outputs. if inverse == True, map from range to domain. weights is by default False. To see the cost, set weights to True. obey_flags toggles whether invalid flag diacritic combinations are filtered out. By default, flags are treated as epsilons in the input. print_flags toggels whether flag diacritics are printed in the output.

become(other)[source]

Hacky or what? We use this to mutate self for those algorithms that don’t directly do it.

classmethod character_ranges(ranges, complement=False) → FST[source]

Returns a two-state FSM from a list of unicode code point range pairs. Keyword arguments: complement – if True, the character class is negated, i.e. [^ … ], and a two-state FST is returned with the single label . and all the symbols in the character class are put in the alphabet.

check_graphviz_installed()[source]
cleanup_sigma()[source]

Mutates the FST, pushing weights toward the initial state. Calls dijkstra and maybe scc.

classmethod re(regularexpression, defined={}, functions={}, multichar_symbols=None)

Compile a regular expression and return the resulting FST. Keyword arguments: defined – a dictionary of defined FSTs that the compiler can access whenever

a defined network is referenced in the regex, e.g. $vowel

functions – a set of Python functions that the compiler can access when a function

is referenced in the regex, e.g. $^myfunc(…)

classmethod regex(regularexpression, defined={}, functions={}, multichar_symbols=None)[source]

Compile a regular expression and return the resulting FST. Keyword arguments: defined – a dictionary of defined FSTs that the compiler can access whenever

a defined network is referenced in the regex, e.g. $vowel

functions – a set of Python functions that the compiler can access when a function

is referenced in the regex, e.g. $^myfunc(…)

render(view=True, filename: str = 'FST', format='pdf', tight=True)[source]

Renders the FST to a file and optionally opens the file. :param view: If True, the rendered file will be opened. :param format: The file format for the Digraph. Typically ‘pdf’, ‘png’, or ‘svg’. View all formats: https://graphviz.org/docs/outputs/ :param tight: If False, the rendered file will have whitespace margins around the graph.

reverse() → FST

Mutates the FST, reversing the FST, epsilon-free.

reverse_e() → FST

Mutates the FST, reversing the FST, using epsilons.

rewrite(*contexts, **flags) → FST

Mutates the FST, rewriting self in contexts in parallel, controlled by flags.

classmethod rlg(grammar, startsymbol, multichar_symbols=None)[source]

Compile a (weighted) right-linear grammar into an FST, similarly to lexc.

save(path: str)[source]

Saves the current FST to a file. :param path: The path to save to (without a file extension) :type path: str

save_att(base: PathLike, state_symbols=False, epsilon='@0@')[source]

Save to AT&T format files for use with other FST libraries (Foma, OpenFST, RustFST, HFST, etc).

This will, in addition to saving the transitions in base, also create separate files with the extensions .isyms and .osyms containing the input and output symbol tables (so for example if base is test.fst, it will create test.isyms and test.osyms)

Note also that the AT&T format has no mechanism for quoting or escaping characters (notably whitespace) in symbols and state names, but only tabs are used as field separators by default, so any other characters should be acceptable (though not always recommended). The symbol @0@ is used by default for epsilon (but can be changed with the epsilon parameter) as this is Foma’s default, and will always have symbol ID 0 as this is required by OpenFST.

If state_symbols is true, the names of states will be retained in the output file and a state symbol table created with the extension .ssyms. This option is disabled by default since it is not compatible with Foma.

Note also that unreachable states are not inclued in the output.

scc() → set

Calculate the strongly connected components of an FST.

This is a basic implementation of Tarjan’s (1972) algorithm. Tarjan, R. E. (1972), “Depth-first search and linear graph algorithms”, SIAM Journal on Computing, 1 (2): 146–160.

Returns a set of frozensets of states, one frozenset for each SCC.

states

A set of all states in the FST

todict() → Dict[str, Any][source]

Create a dictionary form of the FST for export to JSON. May be post-processed for optimization in Javascript.

tojs(jsnetname: str = 'myNet') → str[source]

Create Javascript compatible with foma_apply_down.js

tokenize_against_alphabet(word) → list[source]

Tokenize a string using the alphabet of the automaton.

trim() → FST

Mutates the FST, removing states that aren’t both accessible and coaccessible.

union(fst2: FST) → FST

Mutates the caller FST. Epsilon-free calculation of union of fst1 and fst2.

view(raw=False, show_weights=False, show_alphabet=True) → graphviz.Digraph[source]

Creates a ‘graphviz.Digraph’ object to view the FST. Will automatically display the FST in Jupyter.

param raw:

if True, show label tuples and weights unformatted

param show_weights:

force display of weights even if 0.0

param show_alphabet:

displays the alphabet below the FST

return:

A Digraph object which will automatically display in Jupyter.

If you would like to display the FST from a non-Jupyter environment, please use FST.render

words()[source]

A generator to yield all words. Yay BFS!

words_cheapest()

A generator to yield all words in order of cost, cheapest first.

words_nbest(n) → list

Finds the n cheapest word in an FST, returning a list.

Generator for all transitions out from a given state.

remove_transitions_to_targets(targets)[source]

Remove all transitions from self to any state in the set targets.

rename_label(original, new)[source]

Changes labels in a state’s transitions from original to new.

property transitionsin: dict

Returns a dictionary of the transitions from a state, indexed by the input label, i.e. the first member of the label tuple.

property transitionsout

Returns a dictionary of the transitions from a state, indexed by the output label, i.e. the last member of the label tuple.

pyfoma.paradigm module

class pyfoma.paradigm.Paradigm(grammar: ~pyfoma.fst.FST, regexfilter: str, tagfilter=<function Paradigm.<lambda>>, obey_flags=True, print_flags=False)[source]

Bases: object

__init__(grammar: ~pyfoma.fst.FST, regexfilter: str, tagfilter=<function Paradigm.<lambda>>, obey_flags=True, print_flags=False)[source]

Extract a ‘paradigm’ from a grammar FST. Available as a list in attr para.

Parameters:

  • grammar (FST) – The FST to extract a paradigm for.

  • regexfilter (str) – A regex which is composed on the input side to filter out a specific lexeme or set of lexemes, e.g. ‘run.*’

  • tagfilter (Callable) – A function to identify tags, by default bracketed symbols [ … ]

  • obey_flags (boolean) – Whether to exlcude input-output pairs with invalid flag diacritic combinations

  • print_flags (boolean) – Whether to print flag diacritics in output
